result.execSummary:
The defendant Cassandra J Goodlad was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).
  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

No contact with any victims listed in the complaint.
Provide DNA sample if not previously done.

records.addlTxt:
with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered.  
Pretrial Incarceration Credit form filed.

Timothy Suha appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Cassandra J Goodlad in court with attorney Chris Bailey.

Defendant enters a plea of No Contest to both counts 2 & 3.
Court finds the defendant Guilty of both counts 2 & 3.
Count 1 is dismissed as a read in.

Court orders the following:
Count 2:
6 Months in the Waukesha County Jail w/huber (all standard release conditions).
3 Days Credit.
Consecutive to:  Cases 15CM794 & 15CM795.
STAYED.

Term of Probation:  3 Years.
CONDITIONS OF PROBATION:  
AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended;
Absolute Sobriety;  Random U.A.'s ; 
No Use or Possession of alcohol, controlled substances or drug paraphernalia.
No Use or Possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription;
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of all prescriptions
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
No contact with:  any of the victims listed in the criminal complaint.
Mental Health assessment and follow through.
Compliance with all mental health treatment and medications.
Defendant to sign a medical release for agent.

Costs:  $243
DNA Sample and Surcharge:  Court Waives.
Apply Bail.




Count 3:
Court orders the following:
6 Months  in the Waukesha County Jail w/huber (all standard release conditions).
Consecutive to:  count 2.  
STAYED.

Term of Probation:  3 Years.
CONDITIONS OF PROBATION:  
Same as Count 2.

Costs:  $243
DNA Sample and Surcharge:  Court Waives.
Apply Bail and Refund any balance

Defendant Cassandra J Goodlad in court, in custody, with attorney Chris Bailey.   Bryan C. Bayer appeared for the State of Wisconsin. State presents statements regarding the competency report. Defense counsel is in agreement with the findings of the competency report. Court makes findings and the cases are reinstated as the defendant has been found competent. Defense counsel presents arguments regarding the bail. State objects to any bail modification.  Court modified the bail on 15CM1699, but advised that the defendant take all her prescribed medications as prescribed.  Hearing scheduled for May 11, 2016 at 09:30 am.
Motion hearing on April 25, 2016 at 09:00 am.

Defendant is still at Winnebago Mental Health Center and they want to continue to work with her and defense is requesting a further review hearing. State has no objections. Court grants.  Review hearing scheduled for April 25, 2016 at 09:00 am.

Order of Commitment for Treatment

Defendant Cassandra J Goodlad in court, in custody, with attorney Joseph Smith.   Bryan C. Bayer appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Dr. Christina Engen testified on behalf of the State. Cross examination by attorney Smith. State presents closing arguments and agrees with Mr. Engen that the defendant be found incompetent. Defense presents closing arguments. Court does find the defendant incompetent and she is remanded to HHS (Winnebago) for treatment, court further finds that the defendant is incompetent to refuse medications.  Review hearing scheduled for January 27, 2016 at 01:30 pm.
